column1: Your health care provider may tell you to temporarily stop taking medicines that may affect the test results.

These include: - Antibiotics - Antihistamines - Blood thinners, such as aspirin, that make it hard for the blood to clot - Nonsteroidal inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) Do not stop taking any medicine without first talking to your provider.
It may also be ordered if a member of your family is known to have a bleeding disorder due to platelet dysfunction.
The test can help diagnose problems with platelet function and determine whether the problem is due to your genes, another disorder, or a side effect of medicine.

Decreased platelet aggregation may be due to: - Autoimmune disorders that produce antibodies against platelets - Fibrin degradation products - Inherited platelet function defects - Medicines that block platelet aggregation - Bone marrow disorders - Uremia (a result of kidney failure) - Von Willebrand disease (a bleeding disorder)
